awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Environmental Biology for Pacific Islanders
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Hawaii Manoa, located in Honolulu, HI, will support the training of 12 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. This award is supported by the Divisions of Biological Infrastructure (BIO/DBI) and Oceanic Sciences (GEO/OCE). Research will be conducted at the main campus of the University and its affiliated marine laboratories co-located on the island of O'ahu, Hawaii. The project focuses on training Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders, a group under-represented in STEM. Interns will spend one day each week engaged in group activities (field trips, lectures, and instruction in the ethical conduct of research) and the remainder of the week in mentors' laboratories. Interns will choose mentors from 25 faculty investigating 1) terrestrial ecology and evolution (Depts. of Botany and Biology); 2) marine and coral reef biology (Kewalo Marine Laboratory and Hawaiian Institute of Marine Biology); and 3) animal/plant-microbe interactions (Pacific Biosciences Research Center). These future island leaders will experience quality training to catalyze the development of their scientific careers and benefit their home islands 

A total of 36 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Two-year colleges in the Pacific islands of Palau, the Northern Marianas, Guam, Federated States of Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, and American Samoa, will comprise up to three-quarters of the intern cohort each summer, with the remaining coming from colleges in Hawaii. Students will learn to conduct research, write scientific papers and present research results orally in an end-of-program symposium. Many will present their research results at national scientific conferences and in publications in professional journals.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by BIO/DBI will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to follow their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available at http://www5.pbrc.hawaii.edu/reu/ or by contacting the PI (Dr. Michael G. Hadfield at < hadfield@hawaii.edu>) or the co-PI (Dr. Matthew Medeiros at <mcmedeir@hawaii.edu>).

por.por_cntn:
The island states and territories in the Pacific Islands are feeling the first impacts of global climate change, especially sea—level rise. It endangers their water supplies, food resources and the very islands themselves. It has been important to our REU program to train a cohort of Pacific Islanders to recognize and ameliorate as many of these threats as possible. Forty-one undergraduate students, nearly all members of underrepresented minority groups, and 40 of them from Hawaii and the Pacific Islands, have received extensive training and experience in environmental biological research. They have learned state-of-the-art methods for both field and laboratory research and applied them in individual research projects.  All returned to their home islands or states with an expanded appreciation of environmental problems, ways to evaluate the problems and potential solutions to many such problems. This information has been broadly shared by intern presentations at professional meetings, professional publications and, perhaps most importantly, by discussions and presentations at the interns' home institutions and communities. Many of the interns are now completing baccalaureate degrees, while others are already employed in environmentally important agencies or NGOs in their home islands. These young islanders also formed strong bonds among themselves, creating a special force for interisland communications and sharing of both problems and solutions to the global situation created by nations far from their homelands.
